title: When did you realize it was time to leave Silicon Valley? - Quora

response.answer_text: After the dot-com crash in the early 2000s, followed closely by 9/11, consumer and citizen confidence took a nosedive. I had been working in the Valley since the mid-1990s. Not in tech, but at the ad agencies which were an essential part of selling e-products and services to the masses. “You guys got all the money!” claimed one guy from Thunderbird Business School, whose shared the same North Beach watering hole as me and my ad colleagues. The money, the VCs, the ad contracts and the jobs seemed to disappear within a matter of months. More and more, you’d see former colleagues pulling espresso at Starbucks, or contemplating moving back to wherever they came from. Possibly to return to the employer they had left to chase their dot com dream, possibly to go back to law school or art school or finally chase their dream of teaching yoga in Tulum, Mexico. My boyfriend and I decided to stay. We’d both managed to score some freelance work for the clients our agency used to service. Our rent-controlled apartment was cheap. And we discovered a fun and fairly lucrative side hustle, selling goods people abandoned in their hurry to get out of town. There was a three-month wait for moving vans, so it was common to see piles of furniture, clothes, electronics, and other discarded things with a “free” sign on the heels of a vacancy. We’d go out and gather what we could. TVs, vacuums and VCRs were easy to fix and resell on Craigslist. I remember selling 5 TVs in one day at $50 a pop. We collected nice china and crystal for estate sales; there was still non-dot-com money in town with a taste for luxury items of a bygone era. We also collected certain brand clothing (I remember Levi’s, Patagonia, OP, vintage designer dresses and purses), and sell them to collectors, also on Craigslist. One guy — a middleman to several large boutiques in Japan — would come to our house, dig through our wares and take what he wanted, to the tune of $200-$300 cash. I got to be friends with that guy. We’d prowl thrift shops before a big sale, setting aside the things we wanted and hiding them in racks where they’d be less likely to be discovered (maternity clothing, children’s wear) so we could come during the sale and buy them for half price. We’d also go to flea markets really early, where people would bring out work clothes to sell. We’d dig through the clothes, pulling out vintage Levis with the prized “red tag” and buy them for double the guy’s price. Early bird got the worm, and the worm went to Japan, apparently, where vintage Americana sold for big yen. The freelancing and the vulturing didn’t last. We reluctantly left our lovely Noe Valley apartment, packed up our most-treasured vintage finds, and left for the slightly-less-expensive and less-tech-dependent suburbs of Boston. After a few years, I got sick of Boston and ended up back in Seattle, in a job which has brought me back to Silicon Valley from time to time. I don’t think I’d want to live there again. Seattle has its own problems, but it’s also home to me. I’d never return to the East Coast, but I do enjoy walking the steep streets of my city, now taken over by a new generation of smart and hopeful young things with technological dreams. We’ll see if another bubble bursts. It has to at some point. Maybe some will leave before things get too bad, maybe some will stay long after conventional opportunities have disappeared, maybe some will have the fun of living off the land, for awhile at least.

I’m still here. But I think NOW is a good time to cash out any property you own, and, actually move out of state. I don’t have the time or inclination to list all of my reasons. But to sum it up: I don’t see real estate going up much more, or going down. There is too much uncertainty with Trump’s tax relief, CA taxes, interest rates, and, for now, there are no big pending IPOs in the valley. (Google and Facebook dramatically spiked home prices forever). I suspect there will be oscillations, with no major changes.I don’t believe the economy is set to expand much more, unless, again, Trump’s tax relief does end up heating the economy. But, even if it doesn't help, and it appears to be, rising rates might keep the market tempered. I also suspect oscillations without any near term major changes.So, if you’ve owned property for 10 years or more, and you have a lot of stock options in any company that has been public for 2 or more years.. good time to pack it up. California, which only does well during market booms due to our revenue coming from, mostly capital gains taxes, is set for some serious problems. Public employee unions in CA are and will bankrupt the state (they actually make more money than tech workers in many cases, I’ve written about this in other quora posts, so forgive my laziness for not citing the amazing citation/site that actually lists public employee pensions and salaries for all san jose employees - it’s shocking). This is why we have the highest tax rates in the nation, highest sales taxes, and the most people in poverty, the most homeless, and why college costs have exploded. The revenue crunch will get much worse, and since the state is a one party state, the only response will be to continually raise taxes. Therefore, on one hand, take historical market place and real estate valuations, the bleak future of CA taxes/regulations and apocalyptic city centers, and move. Not sure how much how much upside there is in holding, and the downside is nearly bottomless. I’m leaving the Valley in the next 2–3 years. But I might stay in CA as my income should be in tax free munis (so I say, we’ll see).
